choices.text: Insulin binds to the alpha subunit of plasma membrane insulin receptor on the target cells
Plasma half-life of insulin is 30 minutes
Insulin induces the pyruvate kinase enzyme
Insulin inhibits lipolysis in adipose tissue because of inhibition of Lipoprotein lipase

questions.text: Which of the following is not true about insulin?
questions.solution:
Option wise explanation

Option A: Insulin binds to alpha subunit of plasma membrane insulin receptor on the target cells, which induces a conformational change. This results in the generation of signals which are transduced to beta subunits.

Option B: In the plasma, insulin has a normal half-life of 4-5 minutes. This short half-life permits rapid metabolic changes. A protease enzyme, namely insulinase (mainly found in liver and kidney), degrades insulin.

Option C & Option D: Insulin induces pyruvate kinase & Insulin inhibits lipolysis in adipose tissue because of inhibition of Lipoprotein lipase.

Metabolic effect of Insulin:

Key take away

  • Insulin is a peptide hormone, secreted by beta cell of Langerhans of pancreas
  • Gene for insulin is located on chromosome 11
  • Synthesis of insulin involves two precursors, namely preproinsulin with 108 amino acids and proinsulin with 86 amino acids (mol. wt. 9,000). They are sequentially degraded to form active insulin and a connecting peptide (C-peptide). Insulin and C-peptide are produced in equimolar concentration.
  • C-peptide has no biological activity, its estimation in the plasma serves as a useful index for the endogenous production of insulin.
  • Half-life is only 4 to 5 minutes
  • About 40-50 units of insulin is secreted daily by human pancreas.
  • The normal insulin concentration in plasma is 20-30 microU/ml
  • Factors stimulating insulin secretion are glucose, amino acids and gastrointestinal hormones (secretin, gastrin, pancreozymin).
  • Epinephrine is the most potent inhibitor of insulin release.
  • Anabolic hormones
  • Hypoglycemic hormone

questions.text:
Identify the electrophoretic pattern showing in the image and choose the concerned disease related with it

Band between gamma and beta globulin
questions.solution:
Electrophoresis of serum proteins is conveniently used for the diagnosis of certain diseases.

Option wise explanation

Key take away about Multiple myeloma,

  • Plasma cell cancer,
  • constitutes about 1% of all cancers affecting the population.
  • Females are more susceptible than males
  • Usually occurs in the age group 45-60 years.
  • Malignancy of a single clone of plasma cells, results in the overproduction of abnormal immunoglobulins, mostly (75%) IgG and in some cases (25%) IgA or IgM. IgD type multiple myeloma found in younger adults is less common
  • Light chains (kappa or lambda) of immunoglobulins that are synthesized in excess
  • Decreased synthesis of normal immunoglobulins causing depressed immunity. Hence recurrent infections are common
  • Characteristic pattern of electrophoresis: sharp and distinct band between E-and J-globulins (M band)

questions.text: What is the primary product of the conversion of methionine to homocysteine in the methionine cycle?
questions.solution: Inappropriate question, need revision.

Option A: Arginine is a α-amino- δ-guanidino-n-valeric acid, having following structure:

Key take away

  • Serine and threonine are hydroxyl group containing amino acids
  • Arginine contains guanidine group, arginine is used to produce nitric oxide (NO)
  • Aspargine contain amide group

choices.text: All alpha helices found in proteins are right handed
Beta hairpin motif is most commonly seen motif in proteins
All peptide bonds in proteins exist in cis form
Denaturation disrupts all the structure of the proteins

questions.text: Following statement is true about structure of protein
questions.solution:
Option wise explanation

Key take away:

Primary structure

  • Primary structure denotes the number & sequence of amino acids in the protein.
  • Primary structure is maintained by covalent bonds of peptide linkages.
  • Higher levels of organization and function are decided by primary structure.
  • Insulin is best example of primary structure

Secondary structure

  • Secondary structure denotes configurational relationship between amino acids which are 3-4 residues apart in linear primary sequence.
  • α helix, β pleated sheet, β bend – examples of secondary structure
  • Supersecondary structures are: α-α (Helix-loop-Helix), β-α-β, β-Meander, β-Barrel

Tertiary structure

  • It defines steric relationship of amino acids which are far apart from each other in linear primary sequence, but are close in three dimensional aspect (folding).
  • It denotes final three dimensional structure of protein.

Quaternary structure

  • More than one polypeptide units will aggregate to form one functional protein which is known as quaternary structure.

questions.text: All of the following are biologically important peptides, except
questions.solution:
Option-wise explanation

Option A: Oxytocin: A peptide hormone involved in childbirth and lactation, and also plays a role in social bonding and emotional responses.

Option B: Glutathione: A tripeptide that acts as an antioxidant, protecting cells from oxidative damage and aiding in detoxification processes.

Option C: Creatinine is an anhydride produce of creatine, which is an important peptide.

Option D: Myoglobin is protein.

Detailed explanation about biological important peptides and its examples

Peptides are shorter chains of amino acids, typically ranging from 2 to 50 amino acids, linked by peptide bonds. Examples of biologically important peptides are:

Here are examples of biologically important peptides are:

  • Oxytocin: A peptide hormone involved in childbirth and lactation, and also plays a role in social bonding and emotional responses.
  • Vasopressin (ADH): A peptide hormone that regulates water balance in the body by controlling water reabsorption in the kidneys.
  • Endorphins: Peptide neurotransmitters that act as natural painkillers, reducing pain and enhancing a feeling of well-being.
  • Bradykinin: A peptide involved in blood pressure regulation and inflammatory response, promoting vasodilation and increased blood flow.
  • Angiotensin II: A peptide hormone that constricts blood vessels, increasing blood pressure and stimulating aldosterone release for sodium retention.
  • Glutathione: A tripeptide that acts as an antioxidant, protecting cells from oxidative damage and aiding in detoxification processes.
  • Fibrin Peptides: These peptides are produced during blood clotting, helping form the fibrin mesh that stabilizes blood clots.
  • Defensins: Antimicrobial peptides that are part of the immune system, protecting against bacterial, viral, and fungal infections.

These peptides play critical roles in various biological functions, from metabolism and immune defence to neurological activity and homeostasis.

choices.text: Precipitation of protein by UV rays

questions.text: Which of the following is the method for precipitation of proteins?
questions.solution:
Option wise explanation

Option A: Organic solvents (e.g., ethanol, methanol, acetone) reduce the dielectric constant of the solution, decreasing protein solubility.

Option B: Lyophilization is the process of removing water from frozen biological samples under low pressure by sublimation, turning ice directly into vapor without passing through a liquid phase. It will not precipitate proteins.

Option C & Option D: UV rays and Heat lead to denaturation proteins. Denaturation disrupts the secondary, tertiary, and quaternary structures of proteins, without breaking peptide bonds (primary structure remains intact).

Detailed explanation about protein precipitation:

Precipitation of proteins is a common method used to concentrate, purify, or isolate proteins from a solution. Several techniques are available, with different reagents or conditions that reduce the solubility of proteins and cause them to precipitate. These methods are salting out (ammonium sulphate precipitation), Isoelectric precipitation, detergent precipitation, precipitation by organic solvent, Polyethylene Glycol (PEG) Precipitation etc.

Key take away

  • Salting Out: Proteins precipitate as salt concentration increases because salts compete with proteins for water, reducing the hydration shell around proteins. This is known as Salting Out. Ammonium sulfate is commonly used due to its high solubility and gentle effects on proteins.
  • Isoelectric Precipitation: Proteins have an isoelectric point (pI) where their net charge is zero, reducing solubility and causing precipitation.
  • Detergents disrupt protein solubility and leads to precipitation, especially for membrane proteins, by altering hydrophobic/hydrophilic interactions. SDS (sodium dodecyl sulfate), Triton X-100 etc commonly used detergents.

questions.text: Identify the amino acid derivative
questions.solution:
Option wise explanation

Option D: All above three are amino acids derivatives.

Detailed explanation

Amino acid derivatives are molecules that are structurally related to amino acids but have been chemically modified. Amino acid derivatives are involved in various biological functions, including neurotransmission, hormone activity, metabolism, and as intermediates in biosynthetic pathways.

Various examples of amino acid derivatives:

  • Serotonin: Synthesized from tryptophan and regulates mood, sleep, and appetite.
  • Epinephrine and Norepinephrine: Derived from tyrosine, act as hormones and neurotransmitters regulating stress response.
  • Thyroxine (T4) and Triiodothyronine (T3): Hormones derived from tyrosine and iodine, produced by the thyroid gland, and regulate metabolism.
  • Melatonin: Derived from tryptophan, this hormone is involved in regulating the sleep-wake cycle.
  • Ornithine and Citrulline: Derived from arginine, they are intermediates in the urea cycle.
  • Creatine: Derived from glycine and arginine, it plays a role in energy storage, particularly in muscle tissues.
  • Selenocysteine: A rare amino acid found in some enzymes, where selenium replaces sulfur in cysteine.
  • Beta-Alanine: A component of carnosine, involved in muscle endurance.
  • Hydroxyproline: Derived from proline, essential for the stability of collagen.
  • Gamma-Carboxyglutamate: A derivative of glutamate important in calcium-binding proteins involved in blood clotting.
  • Carnosine: A dipeptide (beta-alanine and histidine) with antioxidant and anti-aging properties.
  • Enalapril: An ACE inhibitor used to treat hypertension, derived from proline.
  • Melanin: Derived from tyrosine, responsible for skin, hair, and eye color.
  • L-Carnitine: Derived from lysine and methionine, important for the transport of fatty acids into mitochondria for energy production.
  • N-Acetylcysteine: A modified form of cysteine that acts as a precursor to glutathione and is used to treat acetaminophen overdose and chronic respiratory conditions.
  • Glutathione: A tripeptide (glutamine, cysteine, glycine) important for detoxification, also important role as an antioxidants
  • Bradykinin: A peptide involved in blood pressure regulation and inflammation.

Key take away

  • Serotonin & Melatonin: Synthesized from tryptophan
  • Dopamine, Epinephrine and Norepinephrine, Thyroid hormones: Derived from tyrosine
  • Ornithine and Citrulline: Derived from arginine
  • GABA: derived from glutamic acid, inhibitory neurotransmitters

choices.text: It is used in the Krebs cycle
It is stored in the liver

questions.text: What happens to the ammonia produced during amino acid catabolism?
questions.solution:
Option wise explanation

Option A: Kreb's cycle started with acetyl Co A (which is produce by breakdown of glucose and fatty acids) and citrate.

Option B: During amino acid catabolism, ammonia (NH3) is produced as a byproduct of the removal of the amino group from amino acids. Since ammonia is toxic to cells, especially in high concentrations, it must be efficiently processed (detoxified) and removed from the body.

The primary site for ammonia detoxification is the liver, where the urea cycle occurs. In this process, ammonia is converted into urea. Urea is then transported to the kidneys, where it is excreted from the body through urine.

Option C: Ammonia can not be stored in liver.

Option D: Since ammonia is lipophilic molecule and very toxic to cells, it cannot excrete unchanged.

Key take away

  • Urea cycle occurs only in liver. First two step in mitochondria and next three steps in cytoplasm.
  • Urea cycle also known as the ornithine cycle.
  • Ammonia is very toxic to brain.

questions.text: Which amino acid can be converted into fumarate?
questions.solution:
Amino acids are degraded into intermediates that can enter the TCA cycle or directly contribute to gluconeogenesis by generating pyruvate or TCA cycle intermediates like oxaloacetate, fumarate, α-ketoglutarate, or succinyl-CoA.

Option wise explanation

Option A: Aspartate converted into fumarate which enter into TCA cycle.

Option B: Glutamate converted into alpha ketoglutarate, intermediate in TCA cycle.

Option C: Valine converted into succinyl CoA.

Option D: Isoleucine (Ile): Yields succinyl-CoA (glucogenic) and acetyl-CoA (ketogenic).

Detailed Explanation:

The catabolism of amino acids involves the breakdown of their carbon skeletons into metabolic intermediates. These intermediates can either be used for energy production or serve as precursors for the synthesis of glucose or ketone bodies.

Based on their catabolic end products, amino acids are classified as glucogenic, ketogenic, or both.

Flow chart or table

Key take away

  • Glucogenic Amino Acids: Produces Pyruvate, α-ketoglutarate, succinyl-CoA, fumarate, oxaloacetate. Examples are rest all
  • Ketogenic Amino Acids: Produces Acetyl-CoA & acetoacetate, examples is only leucine
  • Both Glucogenic and Ketogenic: Amino acids that yield both glucogenic and ketogenic products include Ile, Phe, Tyr, Trp, and Thr
  • TCA cycle (Tricarboxylic Acid Cycle), also known as the Krebs cycle or Citric Acid cycle, is considered amphibolic, meaning it plays a dual role in both catabolism and anabolism.
  • Catabolic: It oxidizes acetyl-CoA derived from carbohydrates, fats, and proteins to CO2 and H2O, producing energy in the form of NADH, FADH2, and GTP/ATP.
  • Anabolic: It provides intermediates for the biosynthesis amino acids, glucose (via gluconeogenesis), fatty acids, and porphyrins.

choices.text: It converts ammonia into glucose for energy
It stores excess nitrogen in tissues
It synthesizes amino acids from urea and carbon dioxide
It detoxifies ammonia generated from amino acid breakdown into urea for excretion

questions.text: What is the significance of the urea cycle in mammals, and how does it relate to nitrogen metabolism?
questions.solution:
Option wise explanation

Option A: Glycogen (carbohydrate sources) can convert into glucose by glycogenolysis. A non-carbohydrate sources like lactate, glycerol, glucogenic amino acids & propionate can convert into glucose by gluconeogenesis. An ammonia cannot convert into glucose.

Option B: Ammonia is toxic at higher concentration, so cannot be stored in tissues.

Option C: It synthesizes amino acid arginine from carbon dioxide and ammonia. Not from urea and carbon dioxide.

Option D: The urea cycle converts toxic ammonia (NH3) into urea, which is then excreted from the body through urine. This process is essential for maintaining nitrogen balance and preventing ammonia toxicity.

Key take away

  • Urea cycle occurs only in liver. First two step in mitochondria and next three steps in cytoplasm.
  • Urea cycle also known as the ornithine cycle.
  • Ammonia is a byproduct of amino acid catabolism.
  • High levels of ammonia are toxic to cells, especially in the brain, where it can disrupt neurotransmission and lead to a condition called hepatic encephalopathy.

choices.text: Insulin decreases amino acid uptake in muscle cells
Insulin enhances the uptake of amino acids and promotes protein synthesis
Insulin inhibits protein synthesis during fasting
Insulin has no effect on protein metabolism

questions.text: Explain how insulin affects protein metabolism, particularly in relation to muscle cells and amino acid uptake.
questions.solution:
Insulin plays a crucial role in protein metabolism, particularly in muscle cells, by promoting amino acid uptake and protein synthesis while inhibiting protein degradation.

Option wise explanation

Option A & Option B: Insulin enhances the activity of specific amino acid transporters on the surface of muscle cells, increasing the uptake of amino acids from the bloodstream into the cells.

Insulin particularly promotes the uptake of branched-chain amino acids (BCAAs), such as leucine, isoleucine, and valine, which are important for muscle protein synthesis.

Option C: Insulin stimulates the mTOR (mechanistic Target of Rapamycin) signaling pathway, which is a key regulator of protein synthesis in cells. The activation of mTOR promotes the initiation of mRNA translation and the assembly of ribosomes, leading to increased protein synthesis.

Insulin upregulates ribosomal function, enhancing the translation of mRNA into proteins, specifically favouring muscle protein production.

Option D: Insulin has anabolic effect on protein metabolism

Key points regarding Insulin's Effects on Protein Metabolism:

  • Enhances amino acid uptake by muscle cells, ensuring a supply of amino acids for protein synthesis.
  • Stimulates protein synthesis by activating the mTOR pathway and increasing ribosomal activity.
  • Inhibits protein degradation, reducing muscle breakdown and promoting muscle maintenance.
  • Preserves muscle mass, preventing muscle wasting in insulin-responsive conditions.
  • Maintains a positive nitrogen balance, supporting muscle growth and repair.
  • Facilitates glucose uptake, providing energy for anabolic processes like protein synthesis.
  • By promoting an anabolic state in muscle tissue, insulin is essential for maintaining muscle mass, enhancing muscle protein synthesis, and supporting overall protein metabolism in the body.

choices.text: Non-essential amino acids must be obtained from the diet
Essential amino acids are synthesized in the body and do not need to be consumed
Essential amino acids must be obtained through the diet, while non-essential amino acids can be synthesized by the body
Both essential and non-essential amino acids can be synthesized by the body

questions.text: Discuss the roles of essential and non-essential amino acids in protein metabolism, particularly in terms of dietary requirements.
questions.solution:
Flow chart or table

So Option C is appropriate among all.

questions.text: Which of the following symptoms is most commonly associated with untreated tyrosinemia?
questions.solution:
Tyrosinemia is a rare genetic disorder in which the body is unable to break down the amino acid tyrosine properly due to a deficiency in certain enzymes. This leads to the accumulation of tyrosine and its byproducts in various tissues and organs, causing clinical features.

Three types of tyrosinemia, based on specific enzyme deficiency and severity of symptoms.

I) Tyrosinemia Type I (Hepatorenal Tyrosinemia):

Enzyme Deficiency: Fumarylacetoacetate hydrolase (FAH)

Symptoms: This is the most severe form and affects the liver and kidneys. It can lead to: Liver failure, Kidney failure, Bone weakness, increased risk of liver cancer. Symptoms usually appear in infancy, but they can also manifest later in childhood.

II) Tyrosinemia Type II (Oculocutaneous Tyrosinemia):

Enzyme Deficiency: Tyrosine aminotransferase (TAT)

Symptoms: Primarily affects the eyes, skin, and mental development. Usually appears in early childhood.

III) Tyrosinemia Type III:

Enzyme Deficiency: 4-Hydroxyphenylpyruvate dioxygenase (HPD)

Symptoms: This is the rarest and least severe type. It primarily affects the neurological system and can lead to: Seizures, Ataxia (poor coordination), Intellectual disabilities. Typically manifests in childhood.

Diagnosis of Tyrosinemia:

  • Tyrosinemia is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern
  • Blood and Urine Tests: Elevated levels of tyrosine and its toxic byproducts in the blood and urine.
  • Genetic Testing: To identify mutations in the specific enzymes.
  • Liver Biopsy: May be performed, especially in Type I, to assess liver damage.

Management:

  • Dietary Management: All types require a strict, lifelong diet low in tyrosine and phenylalanine.
  • Medication: Nitisinone (NTBC) is used in Type I to block the accumulation of toxic byproducts.
  • Liver Transplantation: May be necessary for severe cases of Type I
  • Monitoring: Regular monitoring of liver and kidney function, as well as growth and development, is necessary.
  • Early diagnosis and treatment are critical to preventing serious complications and improving quality of life for individuals with tyrosinemia.

Key take away

So option B is appropriate option.

choices.text: They promote muscle protein synthesis and reduce muscle breakdown during exercise
They are primarily stored as fat during exercise
They have no significant impact on muscle recovery
They are converted to glucose and used as the primary energy source during exercise

questions.text: What role do branched-chain amino acids (BCAAs) play in exercise and muscle recovery, and why are they considered beneficial?
questions.solution:
Option wise explanation

Option A: Branched chain amino acids (BCAAs), esp leucine is the most potent in stimulating muscle protein synthesis (MPS), which is the process of repairing and building new muscle tissue after exercise.

They also help to prevent muscle breakdown (Anti-Catabolic) during and after exercise by reducing levels of muscle protein degradation.

Option B: BCAAs never converted into fat and stored in muscle.

Option C: Supplementing with BCAAs post-exercise has been shown to reduce muscle soreness and improve recovery times by minimizing muscle damage and enhancing repair mechanisms.

Option D: BCAAs are ketogenic esp leucine is purely ketogenic. They are not converted into glucose.

Key take away

  • Branched-chain amino acids (BCAAs) examples are leucine, isoleucine, and valine.
  • Leucine is purely ketogenic amino acids.
  • Leucine: The most important for muscle growth and recovery, stimulating muscle protein synthesis.
  • Isoleucine: Plays a role in glucose metabolism and energy production, as well as muscle recovery.
  • Valine: Primarily involved in preventing muscle breakdown and aiding in energy production
  • BCAAs are critical in optimizing exercise performance, reducing muscle damage, and enhancing the recovery process, making them a popular supplement for both endurance athletes and strength trainers.

choices.text: Chronic stress leads to increased muscle mass and protein synthesis
Chronic stress results in elevated cortisol levels, promoting protein catabolism and muscle wasting
Chronic stress has no effect on protein metabolism
Chronic stress enhances amino acid absorption from the diet

questions.text: What is the impact of chronic stress on protein metabolism, particularly regarding cortisol levels and muscle mass?
questions.solution:
Option wise explanation

Option A: Chronic stress increased protein breakdown (catabolism), resulting in muscle wasting or atrophy

Option B: Chronic stress triggers the release of cortisol, a catabolic hormone that increases muscle protein breakdown.

Option C: Chronic stress has a significant impact on protein metabolism, which can affect muscle health, immune function, and overall well-being.

Option D: Chronic stress can impair digestion and absorption of nutrients, reducing the intake of essential amino acids needed for protein synthesis and muscle repair.

The key points regarding influence of Chronic stress on protein metabolism are:

  • Elevate level of cortisol
  • Increased protein breakdown (catabolism), resulting in muscle wasting or atrophy
  • Inhibition of protein synthesis, reduced anabolic activity
  • Suppressed muscle growth
  • Increased demand for amino Acids: Under chronic stress, amino acids are diverted away from muscle-building processes toward other functions, such as immune response and energy production, weakening muscle recovery and repair.
  • Amino acids are used for gluconeogenesis (the production of glucose) to meet the body's increased energy demands during stress, further limiting their availability for protein synthesis.
  • Negative nitrogen balance
  • Reduced muscle repair and recovery
  • Immune system impairment
  • Impaired nutrient absorption

questions.text: In phenylketonuria (PKU), which compound is often measured in urine for diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option wise explanation

Option A: Tyrosine is excreted in urine in hypertyrosinemia.

Option B: Homogentisic acid is excreted in urine in alkaptonuria.

Option C: Phenyl ketones (like Phenylacetate, phenyl pyruvate & phenyl lactate) are excreted in urine in phenylketonuria. So phenyl acetate is often measured to detect phenylketonuria.

Option D: Urinary ketones (beta hydroxy butyrate & acetoacetate) are excreted in urine in ketosis, which occurs due to prolonged starvation or uncontrolled diabetes mellitus.

Key take away about phenyl ketonuria:

  • Rare genetic disorder that affects the metabolism of phenylalanine
  • Autosomal Recessive
  • Phenylalanine hydroxylase enzyme is either absent or severely deficient.
  • As a result, phenylalanine increases in blood. Also, phenyl alanine converted into phenyl ketones (like Phenylacetate, phenyl pyruvate & phenyl lactate) which are excreted in urine.
  • Symptoms: Intellectual disability, seizures and behavioral problems due to high level of phenyl alanine, Mousy odour in the breath, skin, or urine, due to the accumulation of phenylacetic acid, hypopigmentation of skin
  • PKU is typically detected through routine newborn screening tests, which measure the levels of phenylalanine in a baby's blood. Further confirmation is done through genetic testing to identify mutations in the PAH gene.
  • Lifetime low-phenylalanine diet, which involves avoiding high-protein foods such as meat, dairy, eggs, and nuts.
  • Since phenylalanine is needed to produce tyrosine (which is important for protein synthesis and neurotransmitter production), tyrosine supplements may be required.
  • Severe cognitive impairment & growth and developmental delays if not treated
  • Maternal PKU: Women with PKU who do not manage their phenylalanine levels during pregnancy have a high risk of giving birth to babies with birth defects, including intellectual disabilities, heart problems, and low birth weight (a condition known as maternal PKU syndrome).

choices.text: Kwashiorkor is characterized by muscle wasting, while marasmus results in edema
Kwashiorkor is due to protein deficiency, while marasmus is due to overall caloric deficiency
Both conditions are identical in symptoms and causes
Marasmus occurs in children, while kwashiorkor only affects adults

questions.text: In the context of protein-energy malnutrition, describe the differences between kwashiorkor and marasmus.
questions.solution:
Option wise explanation

Option A: Kwashiorkor is a protein deficiency which characterized by edema due to low albumin level. Whereas marasmus is a primary calorie deficiency which result in muscle wasting, as muscle amino acids are utilized for gluconeogenesis to produce glucose and energy.

Option B: Kwashiorkor is due to protein deficiency, while marasmus is due to overall caloric deficiency.

Option C: Both are under PEM, but both conditions are having characteristic symptoms and causes.

Option D: Both occurs in children. Marasmus is common in child less than one year, whereas kwashiorkor seen in child 1 to 5 years of age.

Table showing comparison between Kwashiorkor and Marasmus

questions.text: Which of the following substrates is necessary for the formation of arginosuccinate in the urea cycle?
questions.solution:
Option wise explanation

Option A: Citrulline and Aspartate attached together and form Argininosuccinate.

Option B: Carbamoyl Phosphate attached with Ornithine and form Citrulline.

Option C: Arginine break down into Urea and Ornithine.

Option D: Alpha keto glutarate and alanine attached together and form pyruvate and glutamate.

Flow chart

Summary of Urea Cycle Reactions

  • Ammonia (NH3) + Bicarbonate (HCO-) + 2 ATP → Carbamoyl Phosphate
  • Carbamoyl Phosphate + Ornithine → Citrulline
  • Citrulline + Aspartate + ATP → Argininosuccinate
  • Argininosuccinate → Arginine + Fumarate
  • Arginine → Urea + Ornithine

questions.text: Which of the following molecules can be synthesized from the intermediates of the urea cycle?
questions.solution:
Option wise explanation

Option A: Creatinine is produced from creatine phosphate in muscles. Creatine is a protein produced from amino acids glycine, arginine and methionine. Creatine phosphate is used as a quick energy source for ATP production during muscle contraction. Once it is dephosphorylated, it spontaneously degrades into creatinine. This conversion is non-enzymatic and occurs at a relatively constant rate in the body, making creatinine levels in blood and urine a marker for kidney function.

Option B: Fumarate is produced from breakdown of Argininosuccinate (in the urea cycle) and from succinate (in the citric acid cycle or Krebs cycle).

Option C: Glucose is produced from lactate, amino acids (mainly alanine and glutamine), glycerol and propionate via gluconeogenesis.

Option D: Under low oxygen conditions (anaerobic conditions), pyruvate (the end product of glycolysis) is reduced to lactate by the enzyme lactate dehydrogenase.

Key take away

  • Creatinine - produced from creatine phosphate
  • Fumarate - produced from arginosuccinate (Urea cycle), succinate (TCA cycle)
  • Glucose - from lactate, amino acids, glycerol, propionate (via gluconeogenesis)
  • Lactate - from pyruvate (anerobic glycolysis)

questions.text: Which cofactor is essential for the activity of carbamoyl phosphate synthetase I, the first enzyme of the urea cycle?
questions.solution:
Option wise explanation

Option A: A list of enzymes for which NADH serves as a coenzyme:

  1. Lactate Dehydrogenase (LDH)
  2. Pyruvate Dehydrogenase Complex
  3. Glyceraldehyde-3-Phosphate Dehydrogenase (GAPDH)
  4. Malate Dehydrogenase
  5. Isocitrate Dehydrogenase
  6. α-Ketoglutarate Dehydrogenase
  7. Beta-Hydroxyacyl-CoA Dehydrogenase
  8. Alcohol Dehydrogenase
  9. Acyl-CoA Dehydrogenase

Option B: A list of enzymes for which FAD (Flavin Adenine Dinucleotide) serves as a coenzyme:

  1. Succinate Dehydrogenase
  2. Acyl-CoA Dehydrogenase
  3. Glutathione Reductase
  4. Dihydrolipoamide Dehydrogenase
  5. Monoamine Oxidase (MAO)
  6. Xanthine Oxidase
  7. Lipoamide Dehydrogenase
  8. Alpha-Ketoglutarate Dehydrogenase Complex (as part of the complex

Option C: A list of enzymes for which ATP serves as a coenzyme:

  1. Carbamoyl phosphate synthetase I (Urea cycle)
  2. Hexokinase
  3. Phosphofructokinase-1 (PFK-1)
  4. ATP Synthase
  5. Na+/K+-ATPase
  6. Protein Kinase A (PKA)
  7. Creatine Kinase
  8. Adenylate Cyclase
  9. DNA Ligase
  10. RNA Polymerase
  11. Myosin ATPase

Option D: A list of enzymes for which biotin serves as a coenzyme:

  1. Pyruvate Carboxylase
  2. Acetyl-CoA Carboxylase
  3. Propionyl-CoA Carboxylase
  4. Beta-Methylcrotonyl-CoA Carboxylase
  5. Carboxylase Enzymes (general category)

Key take away

  • NADH, FADH2 are coenzyme for dehydrogenase group of enzymes
  • Biotin is coenzyme for carboxylase enzymes
  • ATP is coenzyme for synthetase enzymes

questions.text: Which of the following metabolites is typically elevated in patients with HHH syndrome?
questions.solution:
Option wise explanation

Option A: Citrulline elevated in Citrullinemia, Kidney disease.

Option B: Urea elevated in high protein diet, dehydration, kidney diseases etc

Option C: Homocitrulline is elevated in HHH syndrome and Argininosuccinate synthetase deficiency.

Option D: Glutamine is elevated in Liver disease, Severe illness or trauma, Renal failure.

Detailed explanation about HHH syndrome

  • Also known as Hyperornithinemia-Hyperammonemia-Homocitrullinuria syndrome
  • A rare metabolic disorder caused by a deficiency in the enzyme ornithine translocase. This enzyme is crucial for the transport of ornithine and other metabolites across the mitochondrial membrane, which is essential for the proper functioning of the urea cycle.
  • Metabolic Abnormalities: Elevated levels of ornithine and ammonia in the blood due to impaired urea cycle function. Increased levels of homocitrulline in urine.
  • Symptoms:

Elevated ammonia levels can lead to neurological symptoms such as confusion, lethargy, seizures, or coma.

Developmental Delays: Cognitive impairment or developmental delays in children.

Failure to Thrive: Poor growth and weight gain in infants.

Neurological symptoms may also include ataxia, hypotonia, and behavioral changes.

  • Management and Treatment:
    • Treatment focuses on managing symptoms and reducing ammonia levels. Strategies may include:
      • Dietary Management: Low-protein diet to reduce ammonia production from amino acid catabolism.
      • Ammonia Detoxification: Medications that help lower ammonia levels, such as sodium phenylbutyrate or lactulose.
      • Supplements: L-arginine may be supplemented to help stimulate the urea cycle.
      • Liver Transplant: In severe cases, a liver transplant may be considered to restore normal metabolic function.
  • Prognosis: Varies; early diagnosis and management can significantly improve outcomes, but untreated hyperammonemia can lead to serious neurological complications.

Key take away: HHH syndrome is Hyperornithinemia-Hyperammonemia-Homocitrullinuria syndrome

choices.text: It provides energy for the reaction
It acts as an electron acceptor
It facilitates the transfer of the amino group
It is involved in the synthesis of urea

questions.text: What is the role of the coenzyme pyridoxal phosphate in transamination reactions?
questions.solution:
Option wise explanation

Option A: It does not provide energy.

Option B: It cannot acts as an electron acceptor.

Option C: Transamination reactions involve the transfer of an amino group (-NH2) from an amino acid to a keto acid, forming a new amino acid and a new keto acid.

Catalyzed by transaminases or aminotransferases (e.g., alanine aminotransferase (ALT) and aspartate aminotransferase (AST)).

Elevated levels of ALT and AST in the blood can indicate liver damage or disease (e.g., hepatitis, cirrhosis), as these enzymes are released during liver injury.

The coenzyme required for transamination is pyridoxal phosphate (PLP), the active form of vitamin B6.

Option D: It is involved in catabolism of amino acids.

Key take away

  • Transfer of an amino group (-NH2) from an amino acid to a keto acid, forming a new amino acid and a new keto acid.
  • Enzyme is transaminases or aminotransferases (ALT & AST).
  • Elevated levels of ALT and AST in the blood can indicate liver damage
  • Coenzyme is pyridoxal phosphate (PLP), the active form of vitamin B6.
  • Reversible
  • It allows the synthesis of non-essential amino acids (e.g., alanine, glutamate) from common metabolic intermediates

choices.text: All amino acids can undergo transamination
Amino acids such as lysine do not participate in transamination
Transamination exclusively occurs in the liver
Transamination requires NAD+ as a cofactor

questions.text: Which of the following statements about transamination is true?
questions.solution:
Option wise explanation

Option A & Option B: All amino acids except lysine, threonine, proline and hydroxyproline participate in transamination.

Option C: Transamination occurs in all cells, whereas deamination and urea cycle exclusively occurs in the liver.

Option D: The coenzyme required for transamination is pyridoxal phosphate (PLP), the active form of vitamin B6.

Key take away

  • Transfer of an amino group (-NH2) from an amino acid to a keto acid, forming a new amino acid and a new keto acid.
  • Enzyme is transaminases or aminotransferases (ALT & AST).
  • Elevated levels of ALT and AST in the blood can indicate liver damage
  • Coenzyme is pyridoxal phosphate (PLP), the active form of vitamin B6.
  • Reversible
  • It allows the synthesis of non-essential amino acids (e.g., alanine, glutamate) from common metabolic intermediates

choices.text: Enhanced platelet aggregation and endothelial dysfunction

questions.text: Which of the following mechanisms explains how elevated homocysteine levels contribute to cardiovascular disease?
questions.solution:
Option wise explanation

Option A: Factors that increase cholesterol production & increase cholesterol level are:

  • Diet: High intake of saturated fats, Trans fats, Cholesterol-rich foods
  • Genetics: Familial hypercholesterolemia (FH), Genetic variations in LDL receptors
  • Obesity and Overweight
  • Lack of Physical Activity
  • Age and Gender: Aging, Post-menopause (in women)
  • Medical Conditions: Hypothyroidism, Diabetes mellitus, Insulin Resistance and Metabolic Syndrome, Chronic kidney disease etc
  • Excessive Alcohol Consumption & Smoking
  • Chronic Stress

Homocysteine has no effect on cholesterol production.

Option B: Elevated homocysteine levels contribute to cardiovascular disease by damaging blood vessels, promoting oxidative stress, increasing blood clot formation, and contributing to atherosclerosis. Proper intake of B-vitamins and managing other risk factors can help lower homocysteine levels and reduce the risk of cardiovascular disease.

Option C & Option D: Homocysteine has no effect on blood pressure regulation and insulin signalling.

Detailed explanation

Homocysteine is an amino acid that is produced when the body metabolizes methionine. Normally, homocysteine is broken down by vitamins B6, B12, and folate.

Factors Leading to Elevated Homocysteine:

  • Vitamin B6, B12, and Folate Deficiency
  • Genetic Mutations: such as mutations in the MTHFR (methylenetetrahydrofolate reductase) gene, can lead to impaired homocysteine metabolism.
  • Chronic Diseases: Conditions like chronic kidney disease can increase homocysteine levels.
  • Lifestyle Factors: Smoking, alcohol consumption, and a high-protein diet may also elevate homocysteine.

Elevated homocysteine levels, a condition known as hyperhomocysteinemia, have been associated with an increased risk of cardiovascular diseases (CVD), such as coronary artery disease, stroke, and peripheral vascular disease. An elevated homocysteine levels contribute to cardiovascular disease by following mechanisms:

  • Endothelial Dysfunction
  • Thrombosis (Blood Clot Formation)
  • Increased Oxidative Stress
  • Promoting Atherosclerosis
  • Increased Vascular Stiffness

Key take away

  • Homocysteine is an amino acid
  • Produced when the body metabolizes methionine.
  • Vitamin B6, B12, and Folate Deficiency can increase homocysteine level
  • Genetic mutations in methylenetetrahydrofolate reductase gene, can also increase homocysteine level
  • Elevated homocysteine levels contribute to cardiovascular disease by damaging blood vessels, promoting oxidative stress, increasing blood clot formation, and contributing to atherosclerosis.
  • Proper intake of B-vitamins and managing other risk factors can help lower homocysteine levels and reduce the risk of cardiovascular disease.
